Let $f(t)$ be minimal such that, in any two-colouring of the edges of $K_n$, the edges can be partitioned into vertex disjoint monochromatic copies of $K_t$ (not necessarily the same colour) with at most $f(t)$ vertices remaining.

Estimate $f(t)$. In particular, is it true that $f(t)^{1/t}\to 1$? Is it true that $f(t)\ll t$?



A question of Moon \cite{Mo66b}, who proved that $f(3)=4$, at least for $n\geq 8$.

Presumably Erd\H{o}s intended to only ask this question for $n$ sufficiently large depending on $t$. Erd\H{o}s notes that $f(t)\ll 4^t$, by comparing to the Ramsey number $R(t)$.

Burr, Erd\H{o}s, and Spencer \cite{BES75} proved that, for $n$ sufficiently large depending on $t$,\[f(t)=R(t,t-1)+x(t,n),\]where $0\leq x(t,n)<t$ is such that $n+1\equiv R(t,t-1)+x\pmod{t}$.




References


[BES75] Burr, S. A. and Erd\H{o}s, P. and Spencer, J. H., Ramsey theorems for multiple copies of graphs. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. (1975), 87--99.

[Mo66b] Moon, J. W., Disjoint triangles in chromatic graphs. Math. Mag. (1966), 259--261.
